title: Who was the best songwriter among the Beatles? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very good question, and one that will never find a satisfying answer. There is an obviously wrong answer, Ringo. Everyone in the world would admit that, even him. His strength was his drumming and keeping the band together. But what about the other three? George: He did write some of the most interesting songs. For example, Here Comes the Sun, Something, Blue Jay Way, Within Without You, Northern Song. Each was different each had unique attributes, each could be the defining song in almost any 60’s band. Except for the Beatles. It’s hard to say if he was kept down by the writing talents of the other two or if he was inspired by them. John: Well, what can I say? Let’s just confine this to the Beatles songs. Imagine is said to be the best song ever written. (I think it’s a pretty tune and little substance. Anywhere in the western world outside of the US, it’s trite lyrics amount to “let’s be nice for a change”. In the US it’s the Communist Manifesto in a song). The early songs are hard to figure out for the layman, and even for the writers. Help is one of the first songs to layout the writer's psychological problems. Norwegian Wood is a masterpiece in personal storytelling. Nowhere Man is a personal examination. Strawberry Fields is unique in music. Tomorrow Never Knows is ground-breaking and genre-defining. This is just a sample of his output, I’ve missed out many of the best songs of the 20th century, who knows how good he could’ve been if not for his massive heroin addiction. Paul: Probably not as innovative as John, but the music magpie that borrowed from the best. He has a musical mind that is constantly creating. Not that many original ideas, but he took the sounds from others to create some of the best music of all time. Penny Lane is a showpiece of his ability to craft a tune. Yesterday was so good he spent ages asking others if they knew the song because he thought it was so ubiquitous someone else must’ve written it at some time. One of his creations was heavy metal with the huge overdrive on Helter Skelter. Blackbird is probably one of the best anti-racist folk songs out there. He helped develop the recording magic, with tape loops and mellotron. He used the western classical tradition and made it into pop songs. Eleonor Rigby and She’s Leaving Home are great examples of using English folk modes to create pop songs. OK now, here’s the hard bit, who is best… This is THE hard question. What do you mean as best? Is the most influential better than the one who wrote the best song? Is consistency better than flashes of genius? Personally, I would say Paul, John was unique and brilliant and in the top 5 songwriters of all time. But Paul beats him for variability and innovation of fusing classical and pop traditions. I don’t think either of them would be as good if they didn’t bounce ideas off each other. Perhaps the only real answer is Lennon/McCartney. Even apart they needed to one-up each other.

Paul McCartney, John Lennon and George Harrison were all outstanding songwriters. Any music project would kill to have just one of them on board. Overall though, I lean to thinking that Paul McCartney was the strongest songwriter. If you ask people to name The Beatles’ most iconic songs, the most ones you’ll most likely hear are: “I Saw Her Standing There”, “She Loves You”, “I Want to Hold Your Hand”, “Yesterday”, “Hey Jude” and “Let It Be”. Most of those were written mainly by McCartney, except for “She Loves You” and “I Want to Hold Your Hand” which were true collaborations between Lennon and McCartney. McCartney had a real knack for coming up with memorable melodies, and was willing to take on board new influences and experiment. In the last years of The Beatles, he was basically in the driving seat. McCartney also probably had the strongest solo career between 1969 and 1980. Although Lennon and Harrison both had moments of excellence in their solo careers, and McCartney’s solo career was hardly consistent. To be clear, John Lennon was indispensable. He wrote many great songs including “I Feel Fine”, “In My Life”, “Strawberry Fields Forever”, the lion’s share of “A Day in the Life” and “Revolution”. He introduced many new influences to the band’s music and lyrics and a sardonic edge. He was definitely the best lyricist in the band, and “In My Life” stands out as maybe the best lyrics of any Beatles song. And the Lennon-McCartney partnership meant that they acted as a check on each other. Lennon often gave McCartney’s songs more edge, while McCartney made Lennon’s songs more accessible. Given that he didn’t write as much material, I suspect that most people wouldn’t say that George Harrison was their best songwriter. But he was limited towards the end when Lennon and McCartney wouldn’t let him write a greater share of songs, and he had a habit of writing one of the highlight songs of each album. “Something” is one of my favourite Beatles songs, and he also wrote “Taxman” and “Here Comes the Sun”. No-one is going to say that Ringo Starr was the best songwriter, as he only has writing credits to a handful of songs. Most of them weren’t standouts either, though I do enjoy “Octopus's Garden”. And although he did do some good songs in his solo career, it wasn’t as noteworthy as the other three, most of those were covers or collaborations.
